title: Swiss-Market 1989 Porsche 911 Speedster M491
description: This 1989 Porsche 911 Speedster is a Swiss-market example that is said to be one of 69 speedsters optioned with the M491 "Turbo-Look" package, which added front and rear spoilers. This option is said to have been exclusive for Speedsters delivered to Switzerland, New Zealand, and Australia. It is finished in Grand Prix White over black leather and is said to have remained in a collection for approximately 22 years before it was imported to the US. Power comes from a 3.2-liter flat-six paired with a G50 five-speed manual transaxle, and additional features include 16" Fuchs alloy wheels, a limited-slip differential, a black soft top, sport seats, a Clubsport steering wheel, air conditioning, and a Grundig cassette stereo. This 911 Speedster shows 67k kilometers (~42k miles) and is now offered in New York by the selling dealer with a clean Carfax report and a clean West Virginia title.
author: bringatrailer
excerpt: Bid for the chance to own a Swiss-Market 1989 Porsche 911 Speedster M491 at auction with Bring a Trailer, the home of the best vintage and classic cars online. Lot #188,257.
text: This 1989 Porsche 911 Speedster is a Swiss-market example that is said to be one of 69 speedsters optioned with the M491 “Turbo-Look” package, which added front and rear spoilers. This option is said to have been exclusive for Speedsters delivered to Switzerland, New Zealand, and Australia. It is finished in Grand Prix White over black leather and is said to have remained in a collection for approximately 22 years before it was imported to the US. Power comes from a 3.2-liter flat-six paired with a G50 five-speed manual transaxle, and additional features include 16″ Fuchs alloy wheels, a limited-slip differential, a black soft top, sport seats, a Clubsport steering wheel, air conditioning, and a Grundig cassette stereo. This 911 Speedster shows 67k kilometers (~42k miles) and is now offered in New York by the selling dealer with a clean Carfax report and a clean West Virginia title. The car features widened rear bodywork shared with the contemporary 911 Turbo, a fiberglass twin-hump convertible-top rear deck, and a shortened windscreen and side windows compared to the standard Carrera. This example is finished in Grand Prix White with a black soft top and was optioned with the M491 package, which added front and rear spoilers. Staggered-width 16″ Fuchs wheels are mounted with Pirelli P Zero Rosso tires. The M491 package included Turbo-specification brakes, anti-roll bars, trailing arms, and torsion bars. The sport seats are trimmed in black leather, which extends to the door panels. Additional amenities include air conditioning and a Grundig cassette stereo. The Speedster was not equipped with rear seats. The Clubsport steering wheel frames VDO instrumentation including a central tachometer with a 6,300-rpm redline flanked by a 260-km/h speedometer, an analog clock, and gauges for oil temperature, oil pressure, oil level, and fuel level. The six-digit odometer shows 67k kilometers (~42k miles). The 3.2-liter flat-six features Bosch fuel injection and was factory-rated at 215 horsepower and 195 lb-ft of torque. Power is sent to the rear wheels via a G50 five-speed manual transaxle and a limited-slip differential. Decoding the options sticker reveals the following information: L908 – Grand Prix White paint VD – Black leather C10 – Version for Switzerland 220 – Limited-slip differential 491 – Turbo-look 559 – Air conditioning The Carfax report is free of accidents or other damage, and it lists an initial entry in May 2021. html:
This 1989 Porsche 911 Speedster is a Swiss-market example that is said to be one of 69 speedsters optioned with the M491 “Turbo-Look” package, which added front and rear spoilers. This option is said to have been exclusive for Speedsters delivered to Switzerland, New Zealand, and Australia. It is finished in Grand Prix White over black leather and is said to have remained in a collection for approximately 22 years before it was imported to the US. Power comes from a 3.2-liter flat-six paired with a G50 five-speed manual transaxle, and additional features include 16″ Fuchs alloy wheels, a limited-slip differential, a black soft top, sport seats, a Clubsport steering wheel, air conditioning, and a Grundig cassette stereo. This 911 Speedster shows 67k kilometers (~42k miles) and is now offered in New York by the selling dealer with a clean Carfax report and a clean West Virginia title.

The car features widened rear bodywork shared with the contemporary 911 Turbo, a fiberglass twin-hump convertible-top rear deck, and a shortened windscreen and side windows compared to the standard Carrera. This example is finished in Grand Prix White with a black soft top and was optioned with the M491 package, which added front and rear spoilers.

Staggered-width 16″ Fuchs wheels are mounted with Pirelli P Zero Rosso tires. The M491 package included Turbo-specification brakes, anti-roll bars, trailing arms, and torsion bars.

The sport seats are trimmed in black leather, which extends to the door panels. Additional amenities include air conditioning and a Grundig cassette stereo. The Speedster was not equipped with rear seats.

The Clubsport steering wheel frames VDO instrumentation including a central tachometer with a 6,300-rpm redline flanked by a 260-km/h speedometer, an analog clock, and gauges for oil temperature, oil pressure, oil level, and fuel level. The six-digit odometer shows 67k kilometers (~42k miles).

The 3.2-liter flat-six features Bosch fuel injection and was factory-rated at 215 horsepower and 195 lb-ft of torque.

Power is sent to the rear wheels via a G50 five-speed manual transaxle and a limited-slip differential.

Decoding the options sticker reveals the following information:

  • L908 – Grand Prix White paint
  • VD – Black leather
  • C10 – Version for Switzerland
  • 220 – Limited-slip differential
  • 491 – Turbo-look
  • 559 – Air conditioning

The Carfax report is free of accidents or other damage, and it lists an initial entry in May 2021.
